text: when Martha plum a woman from Michigan
wrote these letters the Civil War was
raging and months had passed without a
word from her husband William William
plum was a soldier in the US Army we can
tell from this top letter here that he
was from Michigan and his family is
looking to find find out what they can
about his current situation they didn't
know if he was dead or alive Martha
plums letters are just a few of the
thousands of documents in an enormous
collection known as the United States
sanitary commission records over the
next three years the fate of her husband
and other soldiers once lost in history
will be revealed as archivists and
conservators here carefully restore the
documents opening some of them for the
very first time these pages have been
soaking long enough that the adhesive is
starting to loosen conservators place
the letters and deionized water to
separate them making them easier to read
and handle pry them apart and underneath
here we have a print of an eagle and a
flag they say these letters are the
primary documents for future
dissertations historic tomes and novels
that was a time of great stress anxiety
you know there could be very uplifting
moments in very tragic moments and you
see what it was like to live the Civil
War on a day-by-day basis not knowing
how it was going to turn out this first
batch of letters is finished washing and
ready to come out on a tiny slip of
paper found in the bundle of Martha
plums letters a hospital clerk asked
what became of him Martha plum later
found out her husband died of typhoid
fever
